title: A Phase II Clinical Trial of Interleukin-2 (IL-2) in Patients With Mild to Moderate Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: Neuroinflammation is a significant component of Alzheimer disease (AD). Our group recently demonstrated that regulatory T cells (Tregs) have a compromised phenotype and reduced suppressive function in AD patients, skewing the immune system toward a proinflammatory status and potentially contributing to disease progression. Low dose interleukin-2 (IL-2) is now viewed as a promising immunoregulatory drug with the capacity to selectively expand and restore functional Tregs. This study is a phase II, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to assess low dose IL-2 therapy in AD patients. Up to 40 Alzheimer's disease patients in the mild- to moderate clinical dementia stages (MMSE scores: 12-26) will be randomized to five-day-courses of subcutaneous IL-2 or placebo for a total of 6 months. We will evaluate the safety and tolerability of IL-2 treatment and the possible effects of IL-2 treatment on peripheral and central inflammation. The expected time participants will be in the study is 30 weeks.
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is low‑dose interleukin‑2 (IL‑2), a recombinant cytokine (biologic) given subcutaneously to selectively expand/restore regulatory T cells (Tregs) and reduce neuroinflammation — i.e., it is an immunoregulatory biologic intended to modify an AD disease mechanism (neuroinflammation), not a small molecule, symptomatic cognitive enhancer, or neuropsychiatric‑symptom drug. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act (key extracted details): Phase II, randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled study of subcutaneous low‑dose IL‑2 (five‑day courses repeated over ~6 months) in mild‑to‑moderate AD; endpoints include safety/tolerability and effects on peripheral and central inflammation. The trial rationale and design are described in recent reports. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Act (supporting evidence from prior work): Earlier phase‑1/phase‑2a work showed that low‑dose IL‑2 expands circulating Tregs, modulates inflammatory mediators, and produced trends toward clinical benefit, supporting further study. citeturn0search4turn0search0

Reflect: Although IL‑2 does not directly target amyloid or tau proteins, it targets a disease‑relevant pathogenic process (neuroinflammation) using a biologic agent — this fits best under 'disease‑targeted biologic' rather than the other categories. No significant ambiguity — classification is robust given the trial’s stated mechanism and intervention. citeturn0news12turn0search0
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is low‑dose interleukin‑2 (IL‑2), a cytokine biologic given to selectively expand/restore regulatory T cells (Tregs) and thereby reduce peripheral and central inflammation — i.e., it targets neuroinflammation, a disease‑relevant immune process in AD. citeturn0search3turn0search0

Act: Key extracted details from the trial description and publications — Phase II, randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled study of subcutaneous low‑dose IL‑2 (five‑day cycles repeated over months) in mild‑to‑moderate AD; primary assessments include safety/tolerability and effects on peripheral and central inflammation and Treg expansion. Prior phase‑1/phase‑2a work showed LD‑IL‑2 expands circulating Tregs, modulates inflammatory mediators, and produced trends toward biomarker and cognitive benefit. These points support that the drug’s primary biological target is inflammation/immunoregulation rather than amyloid, tau, synaptic function, etc. citeturn1search1turn1search2turn0search3

Reflect: Mapping to CADRO categories, neuroinflammation aligns directly with category F) Inflammation. The agent is a biologic (IL‑2) used to modulate immune cells, but its mechanism is specifically immunoregulatory (reducing inflammation) rather than multi‑target protein clearance or symptomatic neurotransmitter modulation; therefore 'F) Inflammation' is the most specific and appropriate CADRO classification. No substantial ambiguity in the description; if future data show a distinct primary mechanism beyond immunomodulation, reclassification could be considered. citeturn1search2turn0news12
